feed.title: Combined summary - Let's deploy BIP65 CHECKLOCKTIMEVERIFY!

entry.title: Combined summary - Let's deploy BIP65 CHECKLOCKTIMEVERIFY!
entry.summary: The Bitcoin network has been undergoing discussions regarding the implementation of new features through soft forks and hard forks. While some believe that soft forks provide more flexibility for users, others are concerned about the financial risks during the rollout period. The deployment of CheckLockTimeVerify (CLTV) is a major topic of discussion, with debates about whether it should be added through a hard or soft fork.One major issue with soft forks is the vulnerability of SPV wallets during the rollout period, which can create financial risks. Proposed solutions include introducing new flags for Core or using non-standard opcodes like BIP65 and BIP112. It is essential to measure miner adoption and ensure convergence while ensuring consensus within the community.Mike Hearn has raised questions about the benefits of soft forks, suggesting that hard forks may be preferable to prevent invalid blocks from being created, which poses unnecessary risks for SPV wallets and old nodes. There is ongoing debate over the deployment of BIP65 CHECKLOCKTIMEVERIFY, with some supporting a versionbits mechanism and others advocating for a simpler approach.Arguments for and against hard forks are presented, including the claim that they require everyone to upgrade and that they can lead to schisms, but there is no clear consensus on the matter. The fragility of a soft fork is also discussed, with the risk of double-spends in SPV clients noted.In response to these debates, proposals for new flags and opcodes have been suggested to address these issues, including the proposal for a new flag for Core called --scriptchecks=[all,standardonly,none], which would prioritize correctness by default and allow nodes to opt into pseudo-SPV behavior of a soft fork if desired.The article emphasizes the need for consensus across sub-groups and a careful consideration of the security tradeoffs involved in any proposed changes to the Bitcoin protocol. Overall, the debate highlights ongoing discussions and disagreements around how best to implement changes and reach consensus within the Bitcoin community.
